AU: Oki, T; Kanae, S
AF: Oki, T; Kanae, S
TI: Virtual water trade and world water resources
DE: crop water requirement; evapotranspiration ratio; irrigation water requirement; unit requirement of water resources; virtual water gain; virtual water trade; world water resources assessment
AB: Global virtual water trade was quantitatively estimated and evaluated. The basic idea of how to estimate unit requirement of water resources to produce each commodity is introduced and values for major agricultural and stock products are presented. The concept of virtual water and the quantitative estimates can help in assessing a more realistic water scarcity index in each country, projecting future water demand for food supply, increasing public awareness on water, and identifying the processes wasting water in the production. Really required water in exporting countries is generally smaller than virtually required water in importing countries, reflecting the comparative advantage of water use efficiency, and it is estimated to be 680 km(3)/y for 2000. On the contrary the virtually required water for the same year is estimated to be 1, 130 km(3)/y, and the difference of 450 km(3)/y is virtually saved by global trade. However, solely virtual water should not be used for any decision making since the idea of virtual water implies only the usage and influence of water and no concerns on social, cultural, and environmental implications. Virtual water trade also does not consider other limiting factors than water.

CT: 5th International Conference on Web Information Systems Engineering (WISE 2004)
SP: Australian Comp Sci Soc, Australian Res Council
AB: In the recent years the Web has become an important medium for communication and information storage. As this trend is predicted to continue. it is necessary to provide efficient solutions for retrieving and processing information found in WWW. In this paper we present a new method for temporal web page summarization based on trend and variance analysis. In the temporal summarization web documents are treated as dynamic objects that have changing contents and characteristics. The sequential versions of a single web page are retrieved during predefined time interval for which the summary is to be constructed. The resulting summary should represent the most popular. evolving concepts which are found in web document versions. The proposed method can be also used for summarization of dynamic collections of topically related web pages.

AU: Kusuhara, H; Sugiyama, Y
AF: Kusuhara, H; Sugiyama, Y
TI: Regulation of Transporter Function: relation to metabolic disease
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: transporter; polymorphism; vectorial transport; organic anion
ID: PHARMACOKINETICS; POLYMORPHISMS; MRP2; RAT
AB: A great progress has been made in molecular biology of transporters. Dysfunction of certain kinds of transporters has been shown to cause metabolic diseases. With higher frequency than mutations associated with the diseases, the polymorphisms of transporters have been found which affect protein expression and/or transport activity, causing an interindividual difference in drug disposition. To minimize such interindividual difference, multiple elimination pathways are preferable. We could reproduce the hepatobiliary and renal transport systems in a polarized cell line by co-transfection of uptake and efflux transporters. Such system can be used for screening of drugs with suitable pharmacokinetic properties. Vectorial transport also plays an important role in the barriers of central nervous system. Organic anion transporters such as Oatp2 and Oat3 play a major role in the uptake process at the abluminal membrane of the brain capillary endothelial cells, however, it has not came to final conclusion on the transporters on the luminal membrane. RST is a candidate transporter for hydrophilic organic anions. BCRP had been a candidate, however knockout of Bcrp did not affect the brain uptake of BCRP substrate. Recently, Mrp4 has been identified on the brain capillaries, and it may be involved in the efflux transport at the barriers. Gene expression systems, especially double transfectants, will be helpful for screening drugs with improved brain uptake, and for examining possible drug-drug interaction.

AU: Shitara, Y; Hirano, M; Sato, H; Sugiyama, Y
AF: Shitara, Y; Hirano, M; Sato, H; Sugiyama, Y
TI: Analysis of the mechanism of drug-drug interactions involving transporter-mediated hepatic uptake
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: drug-drug interaction; OATP1B; cerivastatin; rhabdomyolysis
AB: Cerivastatin (CER) is extensively taken up by the liver via transporter(s), followed by cytochrome P450-mediated metabolism. As CER is metabolized by 2 different P450s, CYP2C8 and 3A4 it was believed to have a low frequency of drug-drug interactions (D DI). However, interactions with cysclosporin A (CsA) and gemfibrozil (GEM) have been reported and the latter has caused severe myotoxicity including rhabdomyolysis. We examined their effects on the transporter-mediated uptake and P450-mediated metabolism of CER. CsA inhibited the organic anion transporting polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1: formerly referred to as OATP2/OATP-C)-mediated uptake of CER, but not the microsomal metabolism at low concentrations. GEM and its metabolite, gemfibrozil 1-O-beta-glucuronide (GEM-1-O-glu) inhibited both the OATP1B1-mediated uptake and CYP2C8-mediated metabolism. However, taking their therapeutic unbound concentrations into consideration, although CsA can inhibit the transporter-mediated uptake of CER in clinical situations, GEM and GEM-1-O-glu cannot inhibit both its uptake and metabolism. A report that GEM-1-O-glu is. actively taken up by rat perfused liver and concentrated there suggests that GEM-1-O-glu concentrated in the liver inhibits the metabolism of CER in clinical situations. In conclusion, the mechanism of the DDI between CER and CsA involves the inhibition of transporter-mediated uptake while that between CER and GEM involves the inhibition of P450-mediated metabolism by GEM-1-O-glu concentrated in the liver, possibly. via transporter(s).

TI: Nematode homologs of ABC transporter TAPL (ABCB9)
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

ID: GENE
AB: TAPL (TAP-Like, ABCB9) is an ABC (ATP Binding Cassette) transporter which shows homology to TAP1 (ABCB2) and TAP2 (ABCB3), each subunit of hetero-dimeric peptide transporter TAP (Transporter associated with antigen processing). From sequence similarity with TAP1 and TAP2, TAPL is expected to transport peptides as substrate. However, TAPL's tissue-specific expression and cellular localization suggested that TAPL has its own role different from TAP To investigate the in vivo function of TAPL, we are interested in a model organism the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, in which powerful genetics and molecular biological methods are established. Here we report the identification of three C. elegans TAPL homologs, termed haf-2, haf-4, and haf-9 that have strong sequence similarity with TAPL. To know the haf-4 expression, we generated transgenic animals carrying the translational haf4::GFP fusion construct. As a result of microscopic observation, haf-4 tagged with GFP was highly expressed in larval and adult intestine.

AF: Tohyama, K; Kusuhara, H; Sugiyama, D; Sugiyama, Y
TI: The role of organic anion transporting polypeptide 14 (Oatp14) in the transport of T4 across the blood-brain barrier
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: blood-brain barrier; transporter; Oatp14; T4
ID: THYROXINE
AB: Mouse organic anion transporting polypeptide 14 (mOatp14/Slco1c1) is a member of the sodium-independent organic anion transporter family (Oatp/Slco). mOatp14 is predominantly found in the brain where it is widely expressed, except for the cerebellum. Western blot analysis revealed its protein expression in the brain capillary enriched fraction and choroid plexus, and mOatp14 was found to be localized on the basolateral membrane of the choroid plexus epithelial cells. The present study was aimed at investigating the role of mOatp14 in the blood-brain barrier. Functional expression of mOatp14 in HEK293 cells revealed that T4 and rT3 are high affinity substrates of mOatp14, and T3 is a low affinity substrate of mOatp14. Taurocholate, probenecid and estrone-3-sulfate (E-sul) were moderate inhibitors of mOatp14, whereas digoxin (substrate of Oatp2), benzylpenicillin (substrate of Oat3), and large neutral amino acids had no effect. The uptake clearance of T4 by the cerebral cortex determined using the in situ brain perfusion technique in mice was 3-fold greater than that by the cerebellum, and a saturable component accounted for the major fraction of the total uptake. Taurocholate inhibited the uptake of T4 by the cerebral cortex completely, but the inhibition by estrone-3-sulfate was only partial (50%). These results suggest that transporters play a predominant role in the delivery of T4 to the brain, and mOatp14 accounts for the E-sul inhibitable fraction, at least partly. The absence of an inhibitory effect by digoxin, benzylpenicillin, Leu and BCH on the uptake of T4 by the cerebral cortex suggests that other unknown transporters mediate T4 uptake by the brain.

SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: silkworm; non-specific transport system; antibiotic; molecular weight; oil-water partition
AB: The injection of bacteria that are pathogenic to humans into the silkworm hemolymph leads to death of larvae. Antibiotics used for clinical purposes have therapeutic effects on a silkworm infection model. This model is useful for evaluation of therapeutic effect of antibiotics administrated orally. Antibiotics are transported through non-specific transport system on midgut membrane. We investigated effects of molecular weight and hydrophobicity of compounds on efficiency at non-specific transport systems in silkworm midgut. Water-soluble substrates with high molecular weight (M.W. > 500) were not transported from inside to out side of silkworm midgut. Transport rate of compounds in silkworm midgut well correlated with oil-water partition coefficient values. Cefcapene pivoxil, a hydrophobic prodrug of cefcapene, had faster transport rate in silkworm midgut and higher therapeutic effect on infected silkworm than cefcapene.

AF: Matsuo, T; Namba, T; Takehara, M; Yabe, I; Tsuchiya, T; Kuroda, T
TI: Patch clamp analyses of ion transporters in giant bacterial cells
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: patch clamp; giant protoplast; multidrug efflux pump
ID: MEMBRANE
AB: Patch clamp technique is a very useful method for electrophysiological analysis of ion transporters. However, bacterial cells are too small to be analyzed by this method. We have succeeded in establishing a method. (spheroplast incubation method) for preparing giant protoplasts and provacuoles from Escherichia coli cells. So, it became possible to apply patch clamp technique to bacterial cells. To measure the activity of multidrug efflux pumps by patch clamp technique, we constructed plasmids to overexpress multidrug efflux pumps (NorA, MdfA, NorM, VcaM). However, the cells of overexpressing those proteins were too small to adapt to patch clamp technique. So we examined the condition to prepare more suitable giant protoplasts. It seems possible to measure the activity of multidrug efflux pumps by using the provacuoles in the giant protoplast. We adapted a method for preparation of giant protoplasts of E coli to Staphylococcus aureus. S. aureus cells grew as large as 10 mum in diameter and contained provacuoles inside. We applied a patch clamp technique in the whole cell recording mode to the provacuoles and succeeded in measuring current that represents inward movement of H+ due to respiration.

AU: Tojo, T; Tadakuma, H; Matsushima, K; Funatsu, T
AF: Tojo, T; Tadakuma, H; Matsushima, K; Funatsu, T
TI: Oligomerization of G-protein-coupled receptors is independent of ligand binding in living cells: an analysis using single molecule imaging techniques
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: GPCR; GFP; single molecule imaging; chemokine receptor; oligomer
ID: DIMERIZATION; RHODOPSIN
AB: GPCRs (G-Protein-Coupled Receptors) play critical roles on homeostasis in mammals as receptors for neurotransmitters, hormones, chemokines etc. GPCRs are considered as targets for similar to45% of the medicines for clinical treatments. GPCRs were considered to exist as a monomer on plasma membrane. In the last few years, however, increasing evidence obtained by biochemical analyses implied that GPCRs form homo and hetero-dimers or oligomers. To examine this hypothesis, several chemokine receptors of the GPCR family fused with EGFP at the C terminus were expressed in CHO cells and observed using an objective type total internal reflection fluorescence microscope to facilitate single fluorescent molecule imaging. We demonstrate that constitutive and ligand-independent oligomerization is the relevant feature of GPCRs classified into HIV, chemokine- and chemoattractant-receptors, such as CCR5, CXCR4, CXCR1 and FPR1. These GPCRs exist as constitutive oligomers in a living cell. Each singe oligomer of the GPCR consists of various number of the GPCR molecules. The distribution of the number of GPCR molecules in the oligomers occupied by their ligand is statistically the same as those under absence of the ligand. These results unambiguously support the hypothesis that GPCRs form constitutive oligomers independent of ligand binding.

TI: Structural analyses of CERT, a novel intracellular ceramide transporter.
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: CERT; PtdIns(4)P; ceramide; NMR; transferred cross-saturation
AB: CERT is a ceramide-specific intracellular transporter from endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to golgi aparatus. CERT is composed of two lipid-binding domains, Pleckstrin homorogy (PH) and StAR-related lipid transport (START) domains. PH and START domains of CERT interact with Phosphatidylinositol-4-monophosphate (PtdIns(4)P) and ceramide, respectively. In the present study, we constructed the expression system of the PH domain of CERT, using E.coli and pulified PH-domain uniformly labeled with N-15 and/or C-13. To elucidate the ligand-binding properties of PH domain, we performed NMR titration experiments using dibutyl-PtdIns4P, Inositol(1,4)P-2, phosphate, and PtdIns(4)P/liposome as ligands. Based upon the results, from the NMR experiments, the residues on PH domain that recognize PtdIns(4)P and lipid-membrane surfaces were identified.

TI: Effects of nitric oxide on molluscan olfactory center neurons
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: neurotransmission; nitric oxide; neural oscillation; off action
ID: SLUG LIMAX-MARGINATUS; NETWORK OSCILLATIONS; TERRESTRIAL MOLLUSK; INTERNEURONS; RESPONSES
AB: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter found in various types of central nervous systems, and it. diffuses freely across the plasma membrane to affect neighboring neurons. The terrestrial slug Limax has a highly developed olfactory system, and nitric oxide has a modulatory effect on the neural activity in the olfactory center, the procerebrum. The procerebrum exhibits an oscillatory local field potential (LFP), and the LFP oscillation is modulated by odor stimulation to the tentacle in an isolated tentacle-brain preparation. Application of odorants to the tentacle enhances the LFP oscillation, and this effect was suggested to be mediated by nitric oxide. Slugs learn to avoid odors when they are associated with aversive tastes, and this learning protocol is used to probe the ability of the animal to discriminate between odors. Slugs conditioned to 1-octanol showed aversive behavior to 1-octanol, but did not show aversive behavior to 1-hexanol or 3-methylcyclohexanol. When L-NAME was injected to the animal 1 hour prior to the test, the slug also showed aversive responses to 1-hexanol as well as to 1-octanol, suggesting that nitric oxide is essential for odor discrimination.

AU: Yogo, T; Kikuchi, K; Inoue, T; Hirose, K; Iino, M; Nagano, T
AF: Yogo, T; Kikuchi, K; Inoue, T; Hirose, K; Iino, M; Nagano, T
TI: Analysis of intracellular membrane protein function by small molecule-based chromophore-assisted laser inactivation
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: small molecule-based chromophore-assisted laser inactivation; smCALI; inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor; capacitative Ca2+ entry
ID: INOSITOL 1,4,5-TRISPHOSPHATE RECEPTOR; PROBES
AB: Small molecule-based chromophore-assisted laser inactivation (smCALI) was developed to clarify the physiological function of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor (IP3R) in complex intracellular Ca2+ dynamics in intact living cells. The reported CALI study was mainly based on usage of antibody for target recogntion, therefore, invasive method should be necessary to introduce antibodies into cells when we want to inactivate intracellular target. In contrast, our novel technique, smCALI can be carried out under physiological conditions because membrane-permeant synthetic small molecules are used instead of antibodies for molecular recognition. We synthesized a malachite green-conjugated IP3 analog (MGIP(3)/PM) as a smCALI probe and examined the effect of MGIP(3)/PM-based smCALI in intact DT40 chicken B cells. After smCALI using MGIP(3)/PM, Ca2+, oscillation in response to B cell receptor (BCR) stimulation was drastically inhibited, indicating that IP3R was efficiently inactivated. Thus, genuine physiological phenomenon such as Ca2+ oscillation can be analyzed in intact living cells by smCALI It was confirmed that smCALI was effective at the cellular level, so we then applied smCALI to clarify the mechanism of capacitative Ca2+ entry (CCE), in which involvement of IP3R has been suggested. The thapsigargin-induced CCE remained unaffected in DT40 chicken B cells even after inactivation of IP3R by smCALI, suggesting that activation of IP3R is not essential for CCE. Our results demonstrate that smCALI should be a useful method to study intracellular protein function in living cells.

AU: Sunahara, H; Urano, Y; Nagano, T
AF: Sunahara, H; Urano, Y; Nagano, T
TI: Development of environment-sensitive fluorescence probes in biomembrane
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: BODIPY; photoinduced electron transfer (PeT); environment-sensitive fluorescence probes
AB: Membrane properties regulate key biological process. To investigate the membrane properties, fluorescence technique is frequently used as a convenient approach because of its simplicity and high sensitivity of detection. Here we present the BODIPY derivatives bearing various benzene moiety at the 8-position (Figure 2), for novel environment-sensitive fluorescence probes in membrane the fluorescence property of which is controlled by photoinduced electron transfer (PeT). When the HOMO energy level of the benzene moiety is high enough to cause the PeT, the derivative was scarcely fluorescent. Further, it was revealed that the fluorescence ON/OFF threshold gradually altered in accordance with the solvent polarity (Figure 3). Judging from the solvent-dependent changes of redox potential of benzene moieties and BODIPY fluorophores, it became apparent that the free energy change of PeT from a certain benzene moiety values became smaller when the solvent was polar. The above results suggested that our BODIPY derivatives could be used as environment-sensitive fluorescence probe library. To determine the membrane polarity, we applied these compounds on HeLa cell, and found the threshold of fluorescence ON/OFF (Figure 4). These results suggested that biomembrane is as polar as dichloromethane.

AF: Matsushima, S; Maeda, K; Hirano, M; Kondo, C; Sugiyama, Y
TI: Investigation of the contribution of each transporter expressed in human canalicular membrane to biliary excretion of organic anions.
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: transporter; bile canalicular membrane; double transfectants
AB: It is generally believed that transport of various organic anions across the bile canalicular membrane is mainly mediated by multidrug resistance associated protein 2 (MRP2/ABCC2). However, a number of reports have shown that some organic anions are also substrates of multidrug resistance 1 (MDR1/ABCB1) and/or breast cancer resistance protein (BCRP/ABCG2), implying that MDR1 and/or BCRP could be also involved in the biliary excretion of organic anions in humans. In the present study, by using three kinds of double transfectants expressing both OATP2 and MRP2, MDR1 or BCRP, we examined the substrate specificities and contributions of efflux transporters to the biliary excretion of anionic compounds, estradiol-17beta-D-glucuronide (EG), estrone-3-sulfate (ES), cerivastatin (CER), and pravastatin (PRA) by estimating the efflux clearance normalized by the intracellular concentration in double transfectants and comparing the relative expression level of each transporter between human canalicular membrane vesicles and double transfectants. Our results suggest that not only MRP2 but also MDR1 and BCRP play important roles in the biliary excretion of organic anions in humans. This kind of approach using double transfectants is useful for the rapid identification of the substrate specificity and relative contribution of apical transporters in human liver.

TI: Design and synthesis of subtype- and species-selective peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) alpha ligands
SO: YAKUGAKU ZASSHI-JOURNAL OF THE PHARMACEUTICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
DE: peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR); PPAR alpha; species selectivity
ID: PHENYLPROPANOIC ACID-DERIVATIVES; FATTY-ACIDS; DIFFERENTIAL EXPRESSION; HYPOLIPIDEMIC AGENTS; GAMMA 1; AGONIST; BINDING; DELTA; METABOLISM; CLONING
AB: The molecular pharmacological discovery of the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARalpha) as the master regulator of lipid and lipoprotein homeostasis, and the rapid development of a parallel screening approach to evaluate activity towards other PPAR subtypes (PPARdelta, and PPARgamma) have provided an opportunity to develop novel PPAR alpha-selective, PPARalpha/gamma dual, and PPAR pan agonists. This review focuses on the molecular pharmacology of PPARalpha, and summarizes our current design, synthesis, and evaluation of subtype-selective PPARalpha agonists. The species selectivity of several classes of PPARalpha selective agonists in response to in vitro PPARalpha transactivation activity is also reported. These studies should help us to understand the structure-activity relationships and the mode of interaction between ligands and PPARalpha, and also help to create novel therapeutic choices for the treatment of metabolic disorders.

CT: 218th Symposium of the International-Astronomical-Union on Young Neutron Stars and Their Environments
ID: SATURATION DENSITY; MATTER
AB: The structure of cold and hot dense matter at subnuclear densities is investigated by quantum molecular dynamics simulations. The phase diagrams obtained show that the density of the phase boundaries between the different nuclear structures decreases with increasing temperature due to the thermal expansion of the nuclear matter region.

AU: Nespolo, M; Ferraris, G; Durovic, S; Takeuchi, Y
AF: Nespolo, M; Ferraris, G; Durovic, S; Takeuchi, Y
TI: Twins vs. modular crystal structures
DE: cell-twinning; homologous series; OD twinning; tropochemical cell-twinning; twinning
ID: OD-STRUCTURES; SYMMETRY; POLYTYPES
AB: The crystallographic nature of modular structures is analysed and discussed in terms of their symmetry and structure building operations. The modular crystal structures we discuss in this paper are homogeneous edifices, built by one or more types of modules related by a point-space operation, and the whole structure is described by an ordinary three-dimensional triperiodic space group. Because the term "twin" is often used, with or without modifiers, to describe symmetry operations that act as building mechanisms in modular structures, a comparison is made with twins, that are instead heterogeneous edifices, described not by a space group but by a (polychromatic) point group, where the individuals are related by operations in the vector space. A unifying scheme is proposed where the passage from heterogeneous to homogeneous structures, only apparently justified by a change of dimensions of the individuals, implies a change of space where the operations are defined.

AU: Kamikouchi, A; Morioka, M; Kubo, T
AF: Kamikouchi, A; Morioka, M; Kubo, T
TI: Identification of honeybee antennal proteins/genes expressed in a sex- and/or caste selective manner
DE: honeybee; sex; caste; antenna; olfactory processing
ID: APIS-MELLIFERA L.; ACID-BINDING PROTEIN; MOLECULAR-CLONING; SCHISTOCERCA-GREGARIA; KINETIC-PROPERTIES; BROOD PHEROMONE; CDNA; ESTERASE; BEE; HYMENOPTERA
AB: We identified three candidate proteins/genes involved in caste and/or sex-specific olfactory processing in the honeybee Apis mellifera L., that are differentially expressed between the antennae of the worker, queen, and drone honeybees using SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis or the differential display method. A protein was identified, termed D-AP1, that was expressed preferentially in drone antennae when compared to those of workers. cDNA cloning revealed that D-AP1 is homologous to carboxylesterases. Enzymatic carboxyl esterase activity in the drone antennae was higher than in the workers, suggesting its dominant function in the drone antennae. In contrast, two proteins encoded by genes termed W-AP1 and Amwat were expressed preferentially in worker antennae when compared to those of queens. W-AP1 is homologous to insect chemosensory protein, and Amwat encodes a novel secretory protein. W-AP1 is expressed selectively in worker antennae, while Amwat is expressed both in the antennae and legs of the workers. These findings suggest that these proteins are involved in the antennal function characteristic to drone or worker honeybees.
